qas.question: What is the most common method of organization?
The pitch ratio between any two successive notes is?
All these different methods have what in common?

context: The relative pitches of individual notes in a scale may be determined by one of a number of tuning systems. In the west, the <a0_0>twelve-note chromatic scale<a0_0/> is the most common method of organization, with equal temperament now the most widely used method of tuning that scale. In it, the pitch ratio between any two successive notes of the scale is exactly <a1_0>the twelfth root of two<a1_0/> (or about 1.05946). In well-tempered systems (as used in the time of Johann Sebastian Bach, for example), different methods of musical tuning were used. Almost all of these systems have one interval in common, <a2_0>the octave<a2_0/>, where the pitch of one note is double the frequency of another. For example, if the A above middle C is 440 Hz, the A an octave above that is 880 Hz (info).
